frameDefinitions: A Communicator announces (linguistically or non-linguistically) the  imminent arrival of an Individual or the occurrence of an Event.
An Agent creates a Knot (possibly in a Place and/or with an Instrument).'

The Attaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically connected to something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be connected to each other.
An Agent manipulates a linear entity (the Rope) to form a Knot.
An Agent manipulates a Fastener to open or close a Containing_object (e.g. coat, jar).

The Detaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically detached from something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be disconnected from each other.
frameExamples: The unveiling of Alinghi's keel was <t>heralded</t> by alp horns
Loretta <t>ties</t> the most beautiful bowline I've ever seen.
The robber <t>tied</t> Harry to the chair.
Harry <t>tied</t> the rope into a slipknot.
Mary <t>closed</t> her coat with a belt.
They finally <t>unchained</t> me from my desk at work and I'm leavin town.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Communicator</fen> greets the arrival of an <fen>Individual</fen> or occurrence of an <fen>Event</fen>.
The person who is greeted at their arrival by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
The occurrence which is greeted by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
The symbol-containing artifact whereby a <fen>Communicator</fen> heralds.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Communicator</fen>  heralds.
This role identifies the place where the Communicator heralds.
The Agent is the person performing the intentional act.
The stable configuration of a String which results from tying.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.

The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  It is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> attaches to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> is attached.
The <fen>Connector</fen> forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects an <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the sentient being who manipulates the <fen>Rope</fen>.
The basically linear object which is manipulated by the <fen>Agent</fen> to produce a <fen>Knot</fen>.
The stable configuration of a <fen>Rope</fen> which results from tying.
When the manipulation of the <fen>Rope</fen> takes place.
Where the manipulation of the <fen>Rope</fen> takes place.

This role identifies the item that is closed by the agent with the fastener.
<fex name='Agent'>Lee</fex> <t>buttoned</t> <fex name='Containing_object'>his coat</fex>.
The Agent opens/closes the Containing-object.
This role identifies the fastener that the agent manipulates.
This role identifies the active zone of the container that may be expressed as the direct object of the target verb.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> closes the <fen>Container_portal</fen> or the <fen>Containing_object</fen>.
The location where the closing event takes place.
The individual that causes the <fen>Item</fen> and <fen>Source</fen> to come apart by manipulating the connector.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> detaches from the <fen>Source</fen>.
<fen>Source</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> was attached before getting detached.
This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are detached from each other, resulting in their separation.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> detaches the <fen>Item</fen> from the <fen>Source</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> detaches an <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
listRoleExamples: Sheep scattered from the road as trumpets heralded <fex>his arrival at the castle gates</fex>
<fex>The robber</fex> tied Harry to the chair.
The robber tied <fex>Harry</fex> to the chair.
The robber tied Harry <fex>to the chair</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair  <fex>with a rope</fex>.
The robber tied <fex>Harry's ankles</fex> together.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>at midnight</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>in the basement</fex>.
<fex>Melissa</fex> braided Jessica's hair.
He tied <fex>an electrical cable</fex> around the trunk and his neck before hanging himself .
Jake tied the cravat <fex>into an acceptable knot</fex>.
Terri tied the rope around her waist <fex>before scrambling up the side of the mountain</fex>.
<fex>Harry</fex> uncorked the champagne.
Marcus tied his shoe <fex>with the neon-green shoelaces</fex>.
We zipped <fex>the tent flap</fex>.
They close the bank vault <fex>at precisely 5:35PM</fex>.
Shouldn't you have buttoned that <fex>in the bathroom</fex>?
After a few minutes <fex>he</fex> got up and unchained me from the tree.
Mercer's cell phone vibrated and he unhitched <fex>it</fex> from his belt to flip it open.
Mercer's cell phone vibrated and he unhitched it <fex>from his belt</fex> to flip it open.
When, later, they untied <fex>his ankles</fex>, the ropes were left draped over the beam.
